taxonomy.description: Enhanced taxonomy of manipulative tactics with intent qualifiers and contextual factors.

contextual_factors.description: The apparent role of the writer influences the legitimacy of persuasion.
contextual_factors.example: A politician's use of tribal framing differs from a community organizer's.
Appeals to fear targeting children are more unethical.

tactics.description: Presents a particular solution as the only path to a desired future, fostering a sense of hope and belonging among its supporters.
tactics.example: Join us to build a brighter future!

tactics.description: Evokes anger/grievance to mobilize support.
tactics.example: They stole our jobs!

tactics.description: Evokes fear to influence decision-making.
tactics.example: If we don't act, we're doomed!

tactics.description: Presents a claim as fact without evidence.
tactics.example: Everyone knows taxes are too high.

tactics.description: Creates group loyalty by emphasizing superiority.
tactics.example: We are the true patriots.

tactics.description: Misrepresents an opponent's argument.
tactics.example: My opponent wants open borders.

tactics.description: Blames a group for complex problems.
intent_qualifiers: Legitimate Use (identifying responsible party based on facts)
tactics.example: Immigrants cause economic problems.

tactics.description: Uses emotionally charged words.
tactics.example: Bloodthirsty terrorists threaten us.

tactics.description: Leaves out information to mislead.
tactics.example: This product makes you happy. (without mentioning addictive side effects)

tactics.description: Creates impression by linking ideas or people.
tactics.example: Our candidate is endorsed by respected leaders.

tactics.description: Causes someone to doubt reality.
tactics.example: You're imagining things.

tactics.description: Harasses by demanding evidence without genuine engagement.
tactics.example: Prove your point. Why no sources?

tactics.description: Presents group as inherently more moral.
tactics.example: We are the party of values.

tactics.description: Selectively presents data that supports a position, ignoring contradictory evidence.
tactics.example: Crime rates are falling (ignoring specific types of crime).

tactics.description: Presents only two options, when more exist.
tactics.example: You're either with us, or against us.

tactics.description: Encourages people to do something because everyone else is doing it.
tactics.example: Everyone's buying this, so should you.

tactics.description: Attacks the person, not the argument.
intent_qualifiers: Blatant Manipulation (using personal attacks to invalidate argument)
tactics.example: You can't trust him, he's a liar.

tactics.description: Cites an authority to support a claim.
tactics.example: Experts agree that climate change is a hoax.

tactics.description: Introduces an irrelevant topic to divert attention.
intent_qualifiers: Blatant Manipulation (diverting attention from core issue)
tactics.example: You criticize my policies, but what about your own past?

tactics.description: Argues that something is good because it's always been done that way.
intent_qualifiers: Blatant Manipulation (using tradition to justify harmful practices)
tactics.example: We've always done it this way.

tactics.description: Positive statement
tactics.example: Wow, I got to tell you the energy, the optimism, the enthusiasm that we've got in this room is not something that could be replicated by any other political party in this country...
